title: Felicity Huffman pictured in prison jumpsuit as she serves 14-day sentence
text:
Felicity is serving two weeks in prison(Picture: Splash News)

Felicity Huffman has been pictured in her prison jumpsuit as she serves her two week sentence for her part in the college admissions scandal.

The Desperate Housewives star turned herself in last Wednesday to begin her 14 day sentence, after pleading guilty to paying $15,000 (£12,100) to doctor her older daughter Sophia’s university entrance exams.

And Felicity, 56, was pictured for the first time in her green prison uniform while being visited by family at the Federal Correction Institution in Dublin, California.

So much for orange being the new black.

Wearing glasses, trainers and a white baseball cap, the actress looked sombre as her husband William H Macy and daughter Sophia, 19, were seen arriving at the centre to visit her.

William and Sophia visited the actress at FCI Dublin (Picture: SPLASH NEWS)

Felicity looked sombre on visiting day (Picture: SplashNews.com)

Despite being sentenced to 14 days in prison, Felicity will actually only serve 13 days, and is expected to be released on 27 October.

As well as her prison term, Huffman was also handed a $30,000 (£23,300) fine, one-year of supervised release and 250 hours of community service.

A statement issued to People by Huffman’s rep said: ‘Ms. Huffman is prepared to serve the term of imprisonment Judge Talwani ordered as one part of the punishment she imposed for Ms. Huffman’s actions.

Felicity pleaded guilty to paying for her daughter’s exams to be doctored (Picture: Splash News)

The actress was also issued a fine and community service (Picture: JOSEPH PREZIOSO/AFP via Getty Images)

‘She will begin serving the remainder of the sentence Judge Talwani imposed — one year of supervised release, with conditions including 250 hours of community service — when she is released.’

Speaking at her sentencing hearing, the TV star – best known for playing Lynette Scavo – said: ‘I am deeply sorry to the students, parents, colleges and universities who have been impacted by my actions.

‘I am sorry to my daughter, Sophia, my daughter, Georgia, and my husband, Bill. I have betrayed them all.’

Felicity’s actor husband William H Macy wrote a letter that was read out in court, to explain how their family dynamic has changed in light of the scandal.

The Shameless star said Felicity’s relationship with their daughters Sophia and Georgia ‘exploded on March 12th’ when the news became public.

William wrote: ‘Rebuilding that relationship will be a long process but I also want you to know Felicity has raised two amazing young women.’

Some of Felicity’s Desperate Housewives co-stars, including Eva Longoria and creator Marc Cherry, also wrote letters in defence of her character – although her former castmate Ricardo Chavira tweeted: ‘White Privilege. And I saw Eight years worth of it, so I know what I’m talking about. Accountability and Responsibility don’t mean s*** to these people.’

Felicity was just one of the high profile stars wrapped up in the college admissions scam, with Full House star Lori Loughlin pleading not guilty to a charge of trying to bribe their two daughters’ way into the University of Southern California with $500,000 (£384,000).
